Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing an implied warranty/covenant of habitability and related quiet enjoyment doctrine as applied in many jurisdictions)

First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is included in residential tenancies: a tenant is entitled to possession and the peaceful, use and enjoyment of the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord.

Gurliacci v. Mayer, 424 Mass. 157 (1997).raw_text: Gurliacci v. Mayer, 424 Mass. 157 (1997) (discussing tenant remedies for landlord breaches affecting habitability and enjoyment)
Gurliacci v. Mayer, 424 Mass. 157 (1997).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is included in residential tenancies: a tenant is entitled to possession and the peaceful, use and enjoyment of the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord.
Gurliacci v. Mayer, 424 Mass. 157 (1997).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal procedure/search-and-seizure decision about the legality of a traffic stop and subsequent search under the Fourth Amendment and art. 14. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, residential leases, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the proposition about an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies.
Gurliacci v. Mayer, 424 Mass. 157 (1997).relevant_excerpt: There is no question that the original stop of the automobile for speeding, and the threshold inquiry of Hidalgo in connection with the violation, were valid. The stop and inquiry proceeded in an uneventful manner with the production by Hidalgo of license and registration papers that appeared proper and identified Hidalgo. The trooper also elicited answers from Hidalgo that identified Torres and indicated where the two men had been before the stop.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Decisions of the Massachusetts courts and courts in other jurisdictions have long held that substantial interference with use of an essential portion of the leased premises entitles the tenant to damages and, in some circumstances, other relief.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a rule, attributed to Massachusetts and other jurisdictions, that substantial interference with use of an essential portion of leased premises entitles a tenant to damages and sometimes other relief. Hilder v. St. Peter is a Vermont Supreme Court decision adopting an implied warranty of habitability and describing associated contract remedies; it cites Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway (a Massachusetts case) for the contract‑based view of leases, but does not itself articulate or endorse the specific constructive‑interference rule described in the proposition. Thus, this opinion does not directly support the claimed proposition, even though it relies on some similar modern landlord‑tenant principles.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “The modern view favors a new approach which recognizes that a lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition. Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198, 293 N.E.2d 831, 842 (1973).”
